description:
I often make small items out of clay, sometimes I test the clay from a different location, sometimes I make a piece that is both artistic and functional. In this video I fire three small pieces in the adobe rocket stove and then prepare a hot tea made of a local medicinal plant called sticky monkey flower. Two of the clay pieces are just a test of clay found somewhere else but the third piece is made of clay found by the hut and sculpted like a turtle with five holes to hold cattail torches. Let's see if it works.

Follow me on Facebook.com/PrimitiveSurvivalAdventure
Follow me on Facebook.com/chadzuber
Follow me on Instagram @zuberchad

Camera: Nikon D7200
Sound: Zoom H4N
Editing: Final Cut Pro X on MacBook Air
Location: southern California, USA

Music credits: 

Drums of the Deep by Kevin MacLeod is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution license (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/)
Source: http://incompetech.com/music/royalty-free/index.html?isrc=USUAN1400021
Artist: http://incompetech.com/

After a very cold winter I realized the importance of having a reliable and effective heating source for my adobe hut. Now that the rains are over I can proceed making adobe bricks which I will use to build the walls of the fireplace that will be adjoined to the hut. I spent a lot of time considering how I would accomplish this. I estimate that I will need about 70 bricks to complete the project. It will take me approximately 18 hours of labor to make all the bricks. Then the actual construction will be the easy part. I chose the location of the fireplace to be in the back of the hut that way the hut can be heated from the rocket stove at the front as well as the fireplace in the back. Breaking through the wall was much more difficult than I imagined. The adobe bricks are very tough.

Follow me on Facebook.com/PrimitiveSurvivalAdventure
Follow me on Facebook.com/chadzuber
Follow me on Instagram @zuberchad

Camera: Nikon D7200
Sound: Zoom H4N
Editing: Final Cut Pro X on MacBook Air

Artist: http://incompetech.com/

This is the second day of a new adventure as I explore a wilderness area in search of natural resources and a good location to establish the new hut. I'm carrying with me some essential items that I made and a small amount of food to keep me going for several days. On this day I found some very important resources that will be essential for me to inhabit this region. Watch closely as I put to use these basic primitive tools. You may recognize some of them from past videos such as when I made my small clay cooking pot. This series will be ongoing to be sure to stay tuned for the next video.

*Turn on captions to see subtitles in other languages.
*Please subscribe and enable notifications.

Follow Chad on Instagram @chadzuberofficial
Follow Chad on facebook.com/chadzuber

FAQ (Frequently Asked Questions):

Who films you?  
Me. I travel alone, shoot, edit, upload, everything, all alone. On a few occasions I may be accompanied by a friend.

How many cameras do you use?
Usually I use just one camera. When I have underwater scenes then I also use a GoPro camera. I get different angles by moving the camera around and repeating the action to create a more cinematic viewing experience for the audience.

Where is this place?
In order to protect the integrity of the natural landscape I prefer to be very vague about the locations I use. There are places that I used to visit that were so beautiful and untouched but the consequences of social media brought all kinds of people to visit and sadly some people do not respect nature and have badly damaged these places. Therefore I do not share locations.

Where did you get your sandals?
I first started wearing sandals on outdoor adventures in February 2014. I’m so glad that I did because wearing these Luna Sandals has really helped strengthen my feet. You can see their selection of adventure and running sandals at this link: https://www.lunasandals.com/?rfsn=102280.45562&utm_source=refersion&utm_medium=affiliate&utm_campaign=102280.45562
(Note: I receive an affiliate commission from any sales derived from clicking on the link above)

Do you workout?
Yes, I workout, but not in a gym. I have some weights that I use and also do a lot of bodyweight exercises. I also run and sometimes swim. I hike frequently to collect wild foods and to shoot these videos so I'm very active all the time.

Are you vegan or vegetarian?
I wish I could maintain my health on a primal diet that does not include animals but unfortunately that did not work well and I ended up with health problems as a result of those attempts. From my studies, observations of nature, and personal experience I have come to believe that the best diet for optimal human health is a primal diet (paleo). 

Do you get lonely when you’re alone?
No, I don’t get lonely. I’m actually so busy shooting video, taking photos and doing so many other things like making cordage, cooking, weaving, etc. that I really don’t have time to think about my lonely condition. Sometimes when something profound happens on an adventure I can’t wait to share it with people, but other than that I do not get lonely.

How many languages do you speak?
My first language is English but I also speak fluent Spanish and Portuguese. I also speak very little Russian. I may soon begin learning more languages.

How old are you?
I was born in 1972. At the time of this video I was 48.

Where did you get the music in your videos?
This series is the first one that I am making all the music myself. I recently made a drum and maracas (rumba shaker). I am now using them to create the intro and ending music in my videos, but before in the past I have used royalty free music from several sources including YouTube. Sometimes I bought the music but usually it was free.

My equipment:

Camera: Nikon D7500
Sound: Zoom H4N
Editing: Final Cut Pro X on MacBook Air
Location: Parts Unknown

The queen palm (Syagrus romanzoffiana) is native to South America however it has been introduced to temperate climates around the world. Many people don’t know that the fruits of this palm are edible and can easily be used to make a fermented beverage. In this video I use primitive basket tools that I made to collect the queen palm fruit and then wash and prepare the fruits at a mountain stream then allow them to ferment for one week in my calabash bottle gourd. The final product has a richly unique but pleasant flavor and a thick texture like syrup.

Follow me on Facebook.com/PrimitiveSurvivalAdventure
Follow me on Facebook.com/chadzuber
Follow me on Instagram @zuberchad

Cooking on a fire-heated earthen stove with clay cookware is a truly unique experience and gives a special flavor to food. Quail and prickly pear cactus are native to this region in California. Quail eggs are high in nutrition and are easy to prepare with chopped prickly pear catus leaf. I cooked them together on my clay skillet I had made a year ago. Some salsa and “guacamole” would have made it perfect!

Follow me on Facebook.com/PrimitiveSurvivalAdventure
Follow me on Facebook.com/chadzuber
Follow me on Instagram @zuberchad

The rain from the previous day drenched my newly made adobe bricks and also softened the ground in the hole where I am digging. As I dug deeper I found a greater concentration of clay and decided to try making a small very primitive pot. The clay in this location is very different from the red clay I used at my hut but it is important that I learn to make pots and bowls as this is an important survival skill. This series will be ongoing so be sure to stay tuned for the next video.

*Turn on captions to see subtitles in other languages.
*Please subscribe and enable notifications.

Last week I posted the first video of my primitive cattail boat as I launched from the beach and managed to push the small bushcraft sea vessel through the waves and reach the calmness of the open ocean. This raft or kayak proved to be very stable and reliable on the water as I paddled around for about an hour. In this video, I take the same kayak out again but this time I’m bringing my fishing gear to practice some primitive ocean survival fishing techniques with an artificial lure and fresh bait. During this three and a half hour voyage I found myself among a school of dolphin and even had a visit by a sea lion. Once again the kayak performed very well and I am looking forward to even greater adventures at sea in the near future.

Please subscribe and enable notifications.

After a more restful night I am once again confronted by a swarm of no-see-um bugs then escape to spend the day at a beautiful quiet beach where a heavy rain replenishes my water needs and at the end of a relaxing day I am visited by a friendly green dinosaur. Also, Carl the coconut head is born!

"A Caribbean island experience like no other!
No crew, no cameraman, just me"

Follow me on Facebook/chadzuber
Follow me on Instagram @zuberchad

Source: http://chriszabriskie.com/darkglow/
Artist: http://chriszabriskie.com/

This recent trip around the sun (commonly known as year 2020) was an excellent opportunity for people around the world to return to basic skills of self-reliance, survival and bushcraft. This video is being released at the very last minute of 2020 and highlights many of the great adventures I had and new primitive skills that I practiced. It’s basically all of my videos this year condensed into one great video.
With the close of this year instead of saying “out with the old and in with the new” I’d rather embrace more of the old ways and traditions, and I hope you will too.
I wish you all a wonderful and healthy future!

Follow me on Facebook.com/chadzuber
Follow me on Instagram @chadzuberofficial

THE FINAL EPISODE!
After spending a night intimately close to nature feeling the earth beneath me and the wind caressing me while the heavens above looked down through starry night eyes, I spend some time reflecting upon this experience realizing the benefits and necessity of spending time in nature for a healthy mind, body, and spirit.

"A Caribbean island experience like no other!
No crew, no cameraman, just me"

I venture out to explore the sea on a plastic board I found and despite a light morning rain the symptoms of dehydration become more severe and the situation more dire as I make my way around the peninsula.

"A Caribbean island experience like no other!
No crew, no cameraman, just me"

Although spiny on the exterior once you cut into the juicy green flesh the Pilosocereus royenii cactus, a common site on subtropical islands of the Caribbean, is a tasty and excellent source of water and nutrients.

Follow me on FACEBOOK and INSTAGRAM !!!

Be sure to watch the previous video where I show how I made the yarn from yucca, animal fur, and bird feathers: https://youtu.be/UDlEdO-y5qM
I designed and made this pillow based on the natural materials I found in my area. I wasn’t sure that this primitive technique would actually work but I was pleasantly surprised that it did work, and it worked well to create a pillow that not only provides good comfort and neck support but is also a work of art to look at. The combination of different materials truly make it a one-of-a-kind art piece. This video details exactly how you can make your own pillow from 100% natural materials from start to finish and I even include visual diagrams to help explain the process. This technique is my own creation and there are probably better ways to make a similar pillow so please add suggestions in the comments. Thank you for watching!

*** CC, Closed Captioning, Subtitles ***
